Grape___healthy.description: The grape plant shows no visible signs of disease or pest infestation. Leaves, stems, and fruits are in normal, vibrant condition.
recommendations: Continue regular irrigation and nutrient management
Monitor for early signs of diseases like Black rot or Powdery mildew
Maintain good air circulation through pruning
Apply preventive organic sprays like neem oil or compost tea if desired
Keep the vineyard clean and free from plant debris

Strawberry___healthy.description: The strawberry plant exhibits vigorous growth with no visible signs of disease, pests, or nutritional deficiencies. Leaves are green, and fruits are developing normally.
recommendations: Maintain consistent watering and ensure well-drained soil
Mulch around plants to conserve moisture and suppress weeds
Fertilize as needed based on soil tests
Inspect regularly for early signs of fungal or bacterial infections
Use crop rotation and proper spacing to prevent future issues

symptoms: Yellowing of leaves with blotchy, asymmetrical patterns

Remove and destroy infected trees promptly
Implement area-wide monitoring and vector control strategies

Avoid unnecessary movement of citrus plant material to prevent spread

Cherry_(including_sour)___healthy.description: The cherry plant, including sour varieties, shows robust growth with no visible signs of disease or insect damage. Leaves are vibrant, and fruit development is normal.
recommendations: Maintain proper pruning for airflow and sunlight penetration
Ensure consistent irrigation without waterlogging
Apply balanced fertilizers based on soil tests
Monitor for early signs of fungal diseases like powdery mildew or bacterial canker
Harvest fruits promptly to avoid attracting pests

Pepper,_bell___healthy.description: The bell pepper plant is in optimal health with strong stems, green leaves, and no visible symptoms of disease or pest infestation.
recommendations: Maintain regular watering, especially during flowering and fruiting
Use well-drained, fertile soil with balanced fertilization
Inspect plants weekly for early signs of fungal or bacterial infections
Stake or support plants to avoid stem breakage
Avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity-related disease risks

Peach___healthy.description: The peach tree is in a healthy condition, showing no signs of disease or pest damage. Leaves are green and well-formed, and fruit development is proceeding normally.

Apply well-balanced fertilizers based on soil testing
Prune regularly to improve airflow and reduce disease pressure
Monitor for signs of pests such as aphids or peach tree borers
Apply dormant sprays in winter to prevent fungal infections

Soybean___healthy.description: The soybean crop exhibits healthy growth with uniform foliage, no visible disease symptoms, and optimal pod formation.

Use certified disease-free seeds
Apply nitrogen-fixing inoculants if needed
Regularly scout fields for early signs of pests or nutrient deficiencies
Rotate crops to prevent soil-borne diseases

symptoms: Initial water-soaked lesions on green bolls
Lesions enlarge, turn brown to black, and may ooze fungal spores
Bolls become soft, decay internally, and may fall off prematurely
Lint may be stained and of poor quality
Foul odor may be emitted from rotting bolls

treatments.name: Carbendazim or Mancozeb based fungicides
treatments.application: Spray on bolls and canopy at early symptom appearance
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–12 days, especially during humid weather

treatments.name: Combination fungicides (Carbendazim + Mancozeb)
treatments.application: Spray to prevent secondary infection on bolls
treatments.frequency: As per disease severity

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride (biofungicide)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray on bolls and soil to suppress fungal pathogens

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil (cold-pressed)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray during flowering and boll formation stages

prevention: Avoid overcrowding and ensure good air circulation
Remove and destroy infected bolls and plant debris
Avoid waterlogging and ensure proper field drainage
Follow balanced fertilization to avoid excessive vegetative growth
Time irrigation to avoid wetting of bolls during flowering
safety_tips: Wear protective clothing, gloves, and mask during fungicide application
Avoid contact with skin and eyes
Keep fungicides out of reach of children and animals
Wash treated produce before handling or consumption

Cotton__ Cotton Leaf Curl Virus (CLCuV).pathogen: Cotton Leaf Curl Virus (CLCuV), transmitted by whiteflies (*Bemisia tabaci*)
symptoms: Upward or downward curling of leaf margins
Thickening and darkening of veins
Development of leaf-like enations (outgrowths) on the underside of leaves
Stunted plant growth and reduced boll formation
Significant reduction in fiber quality and yield

treatments.name: Imidacloprid (systemic insecticide) for whitefly control
treatments.application: Spray at early infestation stage targeting the underside of leaves
treatments.frequency: Every 10–14 days as needed

treatments.name: Thiamethoxam or Acetamiprid (systemic neonicotinoids)
treatments.application: Foliar spray targeting whiteflies
treatments.frequency: Repeat based on pest monitoring

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil (Azadirachtin-based)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray during early crop stages to repel whiteflies

organic_alternatives.name: Yellow sticky traps
organic_alternatives.application: Install throughout the field to monitor and reduce whitefly population

organic_alternatives.name: Verticillium lecanii or Beauveria bassiana (entomopathogenic fungi)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray on the crop as a biocontrol agent for whiteflies

prevention: Use resistant or tolerant cotton varieties
Avoid early and late sowing which favors whitefly buildup
Uproot and destroy infected plants to reduce virus spread
Maintain field sanitation and remove weed hosts
Avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizers that promote succulent growth
safety_tips: Avoid spraying during peak pollination hours to protect pollinators
Wear gloves, mask, and goggles while spraying chemicals
Follow label instructions and waiting periods strictly
Store pesticides in original containers away from food and water sources

symptoms: Yellowing and wilting of lower leaves, progressing upward
Leaf margins may become necrotic and curl inward
Vascular browning visible in stem cross-sections
Plants may be stunted and show unilateral wilting
Severe infections result in premature plant death and reduced yield

treatments.name: Carbendazim (systemic fungicide)
treatments.application: Soil drenching around the plant base at early symptoms
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–15 days based on disease severity

treatments.name: Soil application of bio-fungicide Trichoderma harzianum
treatments.dosage: 5–10 kg per acre mixed with compost or FYM
treatments.application: Apply before sowing or during early growth stages

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake or mustard cake
organic_alternatives.application: Incorporate into soil before sowing to suppress soil-borne pathogens

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride seed treatment
organic_alternatives.application: Coat seeds thoroughly before planting

prevention: Use resistant or tolerant cotton varieties
Practice crop rotation with non-hosts like cereals for 2–3 years
Avoid over-irrigation and ensure well-drained soils
Use certified disease-free seeds and healthy seedlings
Maintain field hygiene and remove infected plant debris
safety_tips: Use gloves and masks when handling fungicides or bio-agents
Avoid contact with skin and eyes during application
Wash hands thoroughly after handling chemicals
Follow label instructions and store products safely

symptoms: Sudden wilting of plants, especially during hot, dry conditions
Leaves turn yellow and dry up while remaining attached
Roots show dry rot with black discoloration and shredding
Plants can be easily pulled from the soil due to decayed roots
Reduced boll formation and patchy crop appearance

treatments.name: Carbendazim or Tebuconazole-based fungicides
treatments.dosage: 2 g or ml per liter of water
treatments.application: Soil drenching near the base of affected plants
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–15 days if symptoms persist

treatments.name: Trichoderma harzianum (biofungicide)
treatments.dosage: 5–10 kg per acre mixed with compost or FYM
treatments.application: Broadcast before sowing or as basal dose

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake or castor cake
organic_alternatives.application: Mix in soil during land preparation to reduce fungal load

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens (biocontrol agent)
organic_alternatives.dosage: 10 g per kg of seed or 2.5 kg per acre in soil
organic_alternatives.application: Seed treatment and soil application

prevention: Use well-drained soil and avoid over-irrigation
Ensure proper field sanitation and remove plant debris
Rotate crops with non-hosts like cereals
Use resistant cotton varieties if available
Avoid sowing in infested fields repeatedly
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask while handling fungicides or bioagents
Avoid inhaling chemical dust or spray mist
Wash hands and clothes after application
Store all agrochemicals out of reach of children and animals

symptoms: Spindle-shaped lesions with gray centers and brown margins on leaves
Lesions may enlarge, coalesce, and cause leaf drying
Neck blast causes rotting of the neck just below the panicle, leading to grain sterility
Panicle blast results in incomplete grain filling and white panicles
In severe cases, entire fields show scorched appearance

treatments.name: Tricyclazole (systemic fungicide)
treatments.application: Foliar spray at early symptoms or booting stage
treatments.frequency: Repeat after 10–12 days depending on disease pressure

treatments.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (combo fungicide)
treatments.application: Spray during early flowering stage to control neck and panicle blast
treatments.frequency: Repeat as needed based on scouting reports

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens (biocontrol agent)
organic_alternatives.dosage: 10 g/kg of seed or 2.5 kg/acre in soil
organic_alternatives.application: Seed treatment and soil application at nursery stage

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray
organic_alternatives.application: Spray at early stages to prevent initial infection

prevention: Use resistant or tolerant rice varieties
Avoid excessive nitrogen application, especially in early stages
Maintain proper spacing to reduce humidity in the crop canopy
Destroy infected stubbles and crop residues after harvest
Adopt timely sowing and balanced fertilization practices
safety_tips: Use gloves and mask during chemical preparation and spraying
Avoid entry into sprayed fields for at least 24 hours
Wash equipment and protective gear after use
Store fungicides safely, away from food and water sources

paddy__ Rice Tungro Disease.pathogen: Rice tungro bacilliform virus (RTBV) and Rice tungro spherical virus (RTSV)
symptoms: Stunted growth and reduced tillering
Yellow to orange discoloration of leaves starting from the tip
Older leaves show interveinal chlorosis and may turn brown
Delayed flowering and poor panicle exertion
Grains are poorly filled or sterile, leading to low yield

treatments.name: No direct chemical control for the virus; focus is on vector control
treatments.dosage: 0.3–0.5 ml or g per liter of water
treatments.application: Spray to control green leafhopper (GLH), the vector of Tungro
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–15 days during early growth stages

organic_alternatives.name: Neem-based insecticides (e.g., Neem oil or Azadirachtin)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray at seedling and early tillering stages to deter vectors

organic_alternatives.name: Use of biological control agents like spiders and mirid bugs
organic_alternatives.application: Encourage natural predators in rice ecosystems

prevention: Use Tungro-resistant varieties (e.g., IR64, IR72)
Remove and destroy infected plants early
Avoid planting near old infected fields
Perform rouging in nursery beds to eliminate infected seedlings
Maintain clean bunds and reduce alternate weed hosts of vectors
Synchronize planting in a region to disrupt vector life cycle
safety_tips: Wear protective gloves and mask while spraying insecticides
Avoid overexposure to chemicals—use in early morning or late evening
Wash hands and equipment after application
Store insecticides in original containers away from children and animals

symptoms: Yellowing and drying of leaf tips progressing down the margins
Water-soaked lesions that turn straw-colored and spread rapidly
V-shaped lesions extending from leaf tip downward
Severe infection leads to drying of entire leaves and wilting
Infected fields appear scorched and yield is significantly reduced

treatments.name: Streptomycin + Tetracycline antibiotic mixture
treatments.dosage: 100–150 ppm (0.1–0.15 g per liter of water)
treatments.application: Spray at early appearance of symptoms
treatments.frequency: Repeat at 7–10 day intervals based on disease severity

treatments.name: Copper oxychloride (bactericide + fungicide)
treatments.application: Foliar spray for suppression of bacterial spread
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10 days if conditions persist

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens (biocontrol agent)
organic_alternatives.dosage: 10 g per kg of seed or 2.5 kg per acre
organic_alternatives.application: Seed treatment and soil application to enhance resistance

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray
organic_alternatives.application: Spray at early stages to reduce bacterial load

prevention: Use BLB-resistant rice varieties (e.g., IRBB series)
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer, especially urea
Ensure good drainage and avoid water stagnation
Destroy crop residues and avoid ratooning
Adopt field sanitation and timely sowing
safety_tips: Use protective gloves and mask while preparing and applying sprays
Avoid spraying during hot parts of the day
Wash equipment and hands after handling chemicals
Keep antibiotics and bactericides away from food and water

symptoms: Small, circular to oval brown lesions with gray or whitish centers on leaves
Spots may coalesce causing large necrotic patches
Infected grains may appear discolored (dirty panicle)
Seedlings may show browning of coleoptiles and leaf sheaths
Reduces seed germination and affects grain filling

treatments.name: Propiconazole (systemic fungicide)
treatments.application: Foliar spray at early stages of disease appearance
treatments.frequency: Repeat after 10–15 days depending on disease pressure

treatments.name: Carbendazim + Mancozeb (combination fungicide)
treatments.application: Spray during tillering and panicle initiation stages
treatments.frequency: 2–3 applications at 10-day intervals

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil
organic_alternatives.application: Spray as a preventive measure or at early infection stage

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens
organic_alternatives.dosage: 2.5 kg/acre mixed with compost or FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Apply in nursery and main field to suppress fungal growth

prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds
Avoid dense planting and ensure good aeration
Apply balanced fertilizer (adequate potassium and phosphorus)
Avoid excessive nitrogen which favors disease
Destroy crop debris and follow crop rotation
safety_tips: Wear gloves, goggles, and mask while handling fungicides
Do not store fungicides near food or animal feed
Wash hands and change clothes after spraying
Follow label instructions for safe intervals before harvest

symptoms: Initial greenish-gray water-soaked lesions on the lower leaf sheaths near the water line
Lesions enlarge and turn brown with gray or white centers and irregular margins
In severe cases, lesions spread to upper leaves and panicles, causing lodging
White mycelial growth and sclerotia may be seen on the infected parts
Reduces grain filling, leading to significant yield loss

treatments.name: Validamycin (antibiotic fungicide)
treatments.application: Spray at early appearance of disease symptoms
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–12 days if conditions persist

treatments.name: Hexaconazole (systemic fungicide)
treatments.application: Foliar spray, especially during panicle initiation
treatments.frequency: Repeat after 10–15 days if needed

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens (biocontrol agent)
organic_alternatives.dosage: 2.5 kg per acre with compost or FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Broadcast in nursery and main field to suppress fungal infection

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma harzianum
organic_alternatives.dosage: 4 g per kg seed or 2.5 kg per acre with compost
organic_alternatives.application: Seed treatment and soil application for early protection

prevention: Avoid excessive nitrogen application
Use proper spacing to reduce canopy humidity
Remove and destroy infected plant debris
Avoid continuous rice cropping; rotate with non-host crops
Use tolerant varieties where available
safety_tips: Wear protective gloves, goggles, and mask during spraying
Avoid entering sprayed fields for 24 hours
Store fungicides safely and label clearly
Wash hands and change clothes after application

symptoms: Oblong or irregular brown lesions on flag leaf sheaths enclosing the panicle
Sheaths turn pale to brown and dry out, affecting panicle emergence
Unemerged or partially emerged panicles may rot inside the sheath
Grains become discolored, chaffy, and poorly developed
Affected panicles result in significant yield loss

treatments.name: Carbendazim (systemic fungicide)
treatments.application: Spray during booting stage when symptoms are first observed
treatments.frequency: Repeat after 10–15 days if needed

treatments.name: Hexaconazole
treatments.application: Spray during panicle initiation and early heading
treatments.frequency: Repeat as necessary during favorable conditions

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens
organic_alternatives.dosage: 10 g/kg seed or 2.5 kg/acre with FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Use as seed treatment and apply in field at transplanting

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride
organic_alternatives.dosage: 4 g/kg seed and 2.5 kg/acre with compost
organic_alternatives.application: Seed and soil treatment to reduce sheath rot incidence

prevention: Use disease-free seeds and tolerant varieties
Maintain proper spacing and drainage to reduce humidity
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization
Remove infected panicles and plant debris after harvest
Follow crop rotation with non-host crops
safety_tips: Wear gloves, mask, and goggles while handling fungicides
Do not eat, drink, or smoke while spraying
Clean equipment thoroughly after use
Store chemicals out of reach of children and livestock

sugarcane__ Ratoon Stunting Disease (RSD.pathogen: Leifsonia xyli subsp. xyli (a xylem-limited bacterium)
symptoms: No distinct external symptoms in early stages
Reduced stalk height and diameter in ratoon crops
Uneven growth and stunted appearance in affected patches
Poor ratoon establishment and reduced tillering
Internal symptom includes orange-red discoloration of vascular bundles at the nodal regions

treatments.name: Hot water treatment (physical method)
treatments.dosage: Soak seed sets in hot water at 50°C for 30 minutes
treatments.application: Pre-planting treatment to eliminate the pathogen from seed material
treatments.frequency: Every ratoon cycle or when planting new crop

treatments.name: Antibiotic dip (optional in severe infections)
treatments.application: Dip cane setts before planting
treatments.frequency: Use only under expert advice

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma harzianum
organic_alternatives.dosage: 5 kg/ha mixed with FYM or compost
organic_alternatives.application: Apply to soil to enhance microbial balance and suppress pathogens

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake
organic_alternatives.application: Apply during land preparation to improve soil health and reduce pathogen load

prevention: Use disease-free, certified planting material
Practice hot water treatment of seed cane before planting
Avoid ratooning more than two times in affected fields
Sanitize harvesting tools between fields
Follow crop rotation and field sanitation practices
safety_tips: Wear gloves while handling hot water or chemical treatments
Maintain proper temperature control during hot water treatment
Dispose of infected plant material safely to avoid spread
Keep treatment equipment clean and calibrated

symptoms: Yellowing and drying of top leaves, progressing downwards
Red discoloration of the internal tissues with white patches across the length of the split cane
Foul smell from affected stalks due to tissue decay
Sporulation (black fungal dots) on the inner surface of the cane
External canes may appear normal but are soft and hollow inside

treatments.name: Fungicidal sett treatment (Carbendazim)
treatments.application: Dip cane setts for 30 minutes before planting
treatments.frequency: At planting time; not repeated in field

treatments.name: Hot air treatment
treatments.dosage: Heat setts at 54°C for 8 hours in a hot air chamber
treatments.application: Used in seed treatment plants for large-scale control
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride
organic_alternatives.dosage: 5 kg mixed with 100 kg FYM/compost per hectare
organic_alternatives.application: Soil application around root zone during early crop stage

organic_alternatives.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens
organic_alternatives.dosage: 10 g/kg cane setts or 2.5 kg/acre in compost
organic_alternatives.application: Sett treatment and field application for disease suppression

prevention: Use resistant or moderately resistant varieties
Plant disease-free, healthy setts only
Destroy infected crop residues and stubbles
Avoid ratooning from infected fields
Practice crop rotation with legumes or non-host crops
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask when handling fungicides
Use properly labeled containers and prepare fresh solutions
Dispose fungicide waste as per local regulations
Clean tools and machinery after use to avoid disease spread

symptoms: Prolific sprouting of auxiliary buds resulting in grassy appearance
Thin, narrow, pale green shoots with weak growth
Stunted plants with no millable canes
Bushy appearance at the base of the plant
Failure of flowering and poor root development

treatments.name: Thermal treatment (Hot water therapy)
treatments.dosage: Soak cane setts in hot water at 52°C for 1 hour
treatments.application: Used before planting to kill phytoplasma in infected setts
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

treatments.name: Tetracycline antibiotic (for seed setts only under controlled use)
treatments.application: Dip cane setts for 3–4 hours under expert supervision
treatments.frequency: Only once for seed treatment

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake
organic_alternatives.application: Applied during field preparation to suppress vectors and improve soil health

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride with FYM
organic_alternatives.dosage: 5 kg/acre mixed with 100 kg well-decomposed FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Applied around the root zone to enhance resistance and improve plant vigor

prevention: Use only disease-free and certified setts
Follow hot water treatment for seed material
Control vector insects like leafhoppers using safe insecticides or neem-based sprays
Rogue out and destroy infected clumps immediately
Avoid ratooning from infected fields
safety_tips: Handle hot water treatment with caution and proper equipment
Use protective gear when handling antibiotics or insecticides
Dispose of infected plants far from healthy fields
Avoid indiscriminate use of antibiotics in open fields

symptoms: Irregular light and dark green mosaic or mottled patterns on leaves
Streaking and chlorosis, especially along the midrib
Reduction in leaf width and cane diameter
Stunted growth and poor tillering
Reduced juice quality and cane yield

treatments.name: Roguing and removal of infected plants
treatments.application: Remove and destroy infected clumps at early stages
treatments.frequency: Inspect fields every 15 days for symptoms

treatments.name: Vector control (aphid management)
treatments.application: Foliar spray to control aphids that spread the virus
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 15 days during active vector presence

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray (Azadirachtin)
organic_alternatives.application: Spray on foliage to repel and control aphid vectors

organic_alternatives.name: Yellow sticky traps
organic_alternatives.application: Installed around the field to monitor and reduce aphid populations

prevention: Use virus-free and certified seed material
Plant resistant or tolerant varieties where available
Remove infected plants promptly to reduce virus load
Control aphid vectors through safe insecticides or organic repellents
Avoid ratooning from infected fields
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask while handling insecticides
Wash hands and face thoroughly after spraying
Avoid spraying during windy conditions to reduce drift
Use recommended dosages to prevent phytotoxicity and resistance

symptoms: Emergence of a black whip-like structure (smut whip) from the growing point
Narrow, twisted, and elongated leaves
Stunted growth and excessive tillering
Reduced cane girth and internodal length
Significant reduction in yield and sugar recovery

treatments.name: Fungicidal sett treatment (e.g., Carbendazim)
treatments.application: Dip setts for 30 minutes before planting
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

treatments.name: Hot water treatment
treatments.dosage: Soak cane setts at 50°C for 30 minutes
treatments.application: Used before planting to kill smut spores
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride with FYM
organic_alternatives.dosage: 5 kg per acre mixed with 100 kg well-decomposed FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Apply around the root zone at the time of planting

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake
organic_alternatives.application: Incorporated into soil during field preparation

prevention: Use disease-free and certified seed material
Avoid ratooning in infected fields
Plant resistant or tolerant varieties
Remove and destroy infected clumps immediately
Practice crop rotation and field sanitation
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask when handling fungicides
Avoid contact with eyes and skin while dipping setts
Dispose of infected plant material away from the field
Follow label instructions for chemical handling and dosage

symptoms: Gradual yellowing and drying of lower leaves, progressing upwards
Stunted and weak plants with poor tillering
Red or brown discoloration in internal tissues of cane
Poor juice quality and dry, pithy canes
Wilting and lodging in severe cases

treatments.name: Fungicidal sett treatment (e.g., Carbendazim)
treatments.application: Dip cane setts for 30 minutes before planting
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

treatments.name: Soil application of fungicide (Trichoderma-based)
treatments.dosage: 5 kg per acre mixed with FYM
treatments.application: Apply to root zone during field preparation
treatments.frequency: Once or twice depending on disease pressure

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride with FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Applied in furrows or around the root zone

organic_alternatives.name: Neem cake
organic_alternatives.application: Mixed into soil before planting to suppress soil-borne pathogens

prevention: Use healthy, certified seed setts
Avoid planting in waterlogged or poorly drained soils
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
Avoid ratooning from infected fields
Remove and destroy wilted or dried clumps early
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask when handling chemical fungicides
Ensure proper disposal of infected material
Avoid over-irrigation to prevent disease spread
Apply treatments in well-ventilated conditions

symptoms: Infected plants appear normal until heading stage
Smutted heads emerge earlier than healthy ones
Spikelets are replaced by black, powdery spore masses (smut spores)
Smut spores are dispersed by wind, leaving behind a naked rachis
Yield loss due to complete destruction of grains in infected spikes

treatments.name: Seed treatment with systemic fungicides (e.g., Carboxin or Tebuconazole)
treatments.application: Treat seeds thoroughly before sowing
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

organic_alternatives.name: Hot water treatment
organic_alternatives.dosage: Soak seeds in cold water for 4 hours, then in hot water at 52°C for 10 minutes
organic_alternatives.application: Done before sowing to kill internal smut spores

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma-based bioformulations
organic_alternatives.application: Seed dressing to improve resistance and reduce pathogen load

prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds
Avoid using saved seeds from smutted crops
Adopt crop rotation with non-host crops
Destroy smutted ears before spore dispersal
Timely seed treatment with recommended fungicides
safety_tips: Use gloves and mask while treating seeds with fungicides
Do not use treated seeds for human or animal consumption
Handle hot water treatments carefully to avoid scalding

symptoms: Yellowing or reddening of leaf tips, progressing downward
Stunted plant growth with fewer tillers
Erect, stiff leaves with purple or yellow margins
Delayed heading and poor grain fill
Reduced yield and shriveled grains

treatments.name: Insecticide treatment to control aphid vectors (e.g., Imidacloprid)
treatments.application: Seed treatment before sowing
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

treatments.name: Foliar insecticide spray during aphid infestation (e.g., Thiamethoxam)
treatments.application: Spray at early aphid detection stage
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–15 days if infestation persists

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray
organic_alternatives.application: Spray during early signs of aphid activity to deter vectors

organic_alternatives.name: Yellow sticky traps
organic_alternatives.application: Place in field to monitor and trap aphid vectors

prevention: Use virus-free certified seeds
Avoid early sowing when aphid population is high
Control aphid vectors early in the crop cycle
Remove weed hosts that harbor virus and aphids
Grow tolerant or resistant wheat varieties where available
safety_tips: Wear protective clothing and gloves when spraying chemicals
Avoid spraying during windy conditions
Dispose of pesticide containers safely
Wash hands and clothes thoroughly after handling chemicals

symptoms: Infected plants appear normal until heading
Grains are replaced by bunt balls filled with black, foul-smelling spores
Bunt balls rupture during harvest, contaminating healthy grains
Infected spikes may be slightly darker and have a fishy odor
Reduces grain quality and marketability

treatments.name: Seed treatment with systemic fungicides (e.g., Carboxin or Tebuconazole)
treatments.application: Treat seeds uniformly before sowing
treatments.frequency: Once before planting

organic_alternatives.name: Hot water seed treatment
organic_alternatives.dosage: Soak seeds in cold water for 4 hours, then immerse in hot water at 52°C for 10 minutes
organic_alternatives.application: Done before sowing to kill bunt spores on seed surface

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride seed dressing
organic_alternatives.application: Coat seeds thoroughly to suppress fungal pathogens

prevention: Use certified and disease-free seed
Treat seeds before sowing with recommended fungicides or bioagents
Avoid planting in fields with history of bunt without rotation
Ensure proper drying and storage of seeds to prevent contamination
Practice crop rotation with non-cereal crops
safety_tips: Wear gloves and mask during seed treatment
Avoid inhaling spore-laden dust from bunt-infected grains
Clean equipment thoroughly after use in infected fields
Do not use infected grains for human or animal consumption

symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth appears on leaf surfaces, stems, and heads
Infected areas turn yellow and then brown as tissue dies
Heavy infection leads to leaf curling, reduced photosynthesis, and stunted growth
Lower grain yield and quality in severe cases

treatments.name: Systemic fungicides (e.g., Propiconazole, Tebuconazole)
treatments.application: Spray thoroughly at first sign of disease
treatments.frequency: Repeat at 10–14 day intervals if disease persists

organic_alternatives.name: Sulfur-based fungicides
organic_alternatives.application: Apply as foliar spray early in disease development

organic_alternatives.name: Baking soda solution (sodium bicarbonate)

organic_alternatives.application: Spray weekly as a preventive or at early signs

prevention: Grow resistant wheat varieties suitable to the region
Avoid excessive use of nitrogen fertilizers
Ensure proper field spacing and air circulation
Destroy crop debris and volunteer plants after harvest
Rotate crops with non-hosts like legumes
safety_tips: Use personal protective equipment while spraying chemicals
Wash hands and face after handling fungicides
Keep children and livestock away during and after application
Do not exceed recommended dosage to avoid phytotoxicity

wheat__Rust Diseases (most significant g.pathogen: Puccinia spp. (Puccinia triticina - Leaf Rust, Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici - Stem Rust, Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici - Stripe Rust)
symptoms: Leaf Rust: Small, round, orange-red pustules mainly on leaves
Stem Rust: Large, elongated reddish-brown pustules on stems, leaves, and leaf sheaths
Stripe Rust: Yellowish, elongated pustules forming stripes on leaves and leaf sheaths
All types cause early leaf drying, reduced photosynthesis, and grain shriveling
Severe infections lead to significant yield and quality loss

treatments.name: Systemic fungicides (e.g., Propiconazole, Tebuconazole, Triadimefon)
treatments.application: Spray at disease onset or during early growth stages
treatments.frequency: Repeat after 10–15 days if conditions are favorable for disease

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil or extract
organic_alternatives.application: Use as a preventive foliar spray during early crop stages

organic_alternatives.name: Cow dung and cow urine-based sprays (Panchagavya)
organic_alternatives.application: Apply at early stages to promote plant immunity

prevention: Grow rust-resistant wheat varieties suited for the local area
Timely sowing to avoid peak infection periods
Monitor crops regularly for early symptoms
Avoid excessive irrigation and nitrogen application
Practice crop rotation and remove volunteer wheat plants
safety_tips: Wear protective clothing and mask while spraying fungicides
Avoid entering fields for 24 hours after application
Keep fungicides away from children and food
Follow label instructions for dosage and safety guidelines

wheat__Wheat Streak Mosaic Virus (WSMV).pathogen: Wheat streak mosaic virus (WSMV), transmitted by wheat curl mite (Aceria tosichella)
symptoms: Yellow streaks and mosaic patterns on leaves
Stunted plant growth and reduced tillering
Delayed heading and poor grain filling
Symptoms often more severe in warmer temperatures
Yield losses can be significant if infection occurs early

treatments.name: No direct chemical treatment for WSMV
treatments.application: Focus is on vector control and cultural practices
treatments.frequency: Implement before and during the crop season

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil (for mite vector suppression)
organic_alternatives.application: Foliar spray to deter wheat curl mites early in the season

organic_alternatives.name: Garlic-chili spray
organic_alternatives.application: Repels mites and enhances plant immunity

prevention: Plant resistant wheat varieties if available
Control volunteer wheat and grassy weeds (green bridge hosts)
Delay planting to avoid peak vector activity
Avoid planting near infected fields
Maintain field hygiene and monitor mite populations
safety_tips: Use protective gloves and mask when applying any organic or chemical sprays
Ensure proper disposal of infected plant material
Wash hands thoroughly after handling plants showing symptoms

symptoms: Pale green to yellowish spots on older leaves
Grayish-violet fuzzy fungal growth on the leaf surface during humid conditions
Leaves collapse and die prematurely
Bulb size and quality are significantly reduced
Infected plants may become more prone to secondary infections

treatments.name: Fungicides (e.g., Metalaxyl + Mancozeb)
treatments.application: Spray thoroughly on foliage during early signs of disease
treatments.frequency: Every 7–10 days during high humidity or wet conditions

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil
organic_alternatives.application: Spray early in the morning or late evening to reduce humidity and suppress pathogen growth

organic_alternatives.name: Garlic extract
organic_alternatives.application: Used as foliar spray to inhibit fungal spore germination

prevention: Use disease-free seeds or seedlings
Provide adequate spacing for air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation especially in the evening
Remove and destroy infected leaves and debris
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
safety_tips: Wear protective gloves, goggles, and a mask during application
Avoid entering the field until spray has dried
Wash hands and clothes after handling fungicides
Do not harvest onions immediately after fungicide application

symptoms: Black, elongated lesions on cotyledons and first true leaves
Dark smutty streaks or swellings at the base of seedlings
Distorted and stunted seedling growth
In severe infections, seedlings may die before emerging
Older plants may develop secondary infections and fail to bulb properly

treatments.name: Seed treatment with fungicides (e.g., Thiram or Captan)
treatments.application: Coat seeds evenly before sowing
treatments.frequency: Single treatment before planting

organic_alternatives.name: Hot water seed treatment
organic_alternatives.application: Prevents initial infection from seedborne smut spores

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma viride
organic_alternatives.application: Seed biopriming before sowing to suppress pathogen

prevention: Use certified disease-free seed
Practice 3–4 year crop rotation with non-host crops
Avoid planting in fields with history of onion smut
Treat soil with compost and biocontrol agents to reduce pathogen load
Maintain optimal soil conditions for seedling growth
safety_tips: Use gloves and mask when handling seed treatments
Store treated seed separately and label properly
Dispose of infected seedlings away from the field
Wash hands thoroughly after handling seeds or soil

symptoms: Soft, watery decay at the base of the bulb and neck
Foul-smelling, mushy tissue that collapses easily
Yellowing and wilting of leaves in advanced stages
Bulbs may show translucent, glassy appearance
Rapid spread during warm and humid conditions

treatments.name: Copper-based bactericides
treatments.dosage: 2–3 g or ml per liter of water
treatments.application: Spray on leaves and neck area of the plant
treatments.frequency: Apply every 7–10 days during high humidity

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray
organic_alternatives.application: Spray preventively during early growth stages

organic_alternatives.name: Bacillus subtilis-based bioformulations
organic_alternatives.application: Apply as foliar spray to suppress bacterial growth

prevention: Use well-drained soils and avoid over-irrigation
Harvest only during dry weather and cure bulbs properly
Handle bulbs carefully to avoid bruising and injuries
Store bulbs in cool, dry, and well-ventilated conditions
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization
safety_tips: Wear gloves and eye protection when spraying chemicals
Do not consume rotting or suspect bulbs
Wash hands and equipment after fieldwork
Ensure proper disposal of infected plant debris

symptoms: Small, water-soaked lesions on older leaves that turn brown and elongate
Lesions coalesce, causing extensive leaf blighting and collapse
Premature leaf death leading to reduced bulb size and yield
Dark brown to black sporulation seen on dead tissues under humid conditions

treatments.name: Fungicide spray with Mancozeb or Azoxystrobin
treatments.dosage: 2–2.5 g or ml per liter of water
treatments.application: Spray uniformly over foliage at the first sign of disease
treatments.frequency: Repeat every 10–14 days during high humidity

organic_alternatives.name: Neem oil spray
organic_alternatives.application: Apply as preventive foliar spray during early growth

organic_alternatives.name: Trichoderma harzianum
organic_alternatives.dosage: 5 kg/acre mixed with compost or FYM
organic_alternatives.application: Apply near root zone to suppress pathogen build-up

prevention: Avoid overhead irrigation to minimize leaf wetness
Ensure good air circulation by proper plant spacing
Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant debris
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops
Apply fungicides preventively during wet and humid periods
safety_tips: Wear protective clothing and masks when spraying chemicals
Wash hands and equipment after use
Do not re-enter sprayed areas until spray has dried
Store fungicides away from food and children

symptoms: Black, powdery fungal growth on the surface of bulbs, especially around the neck and injured areas
Softening and decay of outer bulb scales
Unpleasant odor and shrinkage of affected bulbs
Most common in stored onions or during transit under warm and humid conditions

treatments.name: Post-harvest fungicide treatment with Thiabendazole
treatments.dosage: As per label (commonly 0.5–1 ml per liter of water)
treatments.application: Dip or spray bulbs before storage
treatments.frequency: Single application post-harvest

organic_alternatives.name: Clove or cinnamon essential oil
organic_alternatives.application: Spray or dip bulbs before storage to reduce fungal load

organic_alternatives.name: Neem leaf extract
organic_alternatives.application: Spray during pre-harvest and bulb curing

prevention: Cure bulbs properly before storage (drying at 30–35°C for 10–15 days)
Avoid bruising and mechanical injuries during harvest and handling
Store onions in cool, dry, and well-ventilated areas
Use clean containers and storage bins
Harvest at full maturity to reduce susceptibility
safety_tips: Avoid consuming visibly moldy onions
Handle fungicides and oils with gloves and protective eyewear
Ensure treated bulbs are clearly marked for storage use only
Wash hands thoroughly after treatment applications
